38918964.review:
This game is indeed an experience. You have many choices, you shape your personality, you change the fates of other 'Teks', the robot inhabitants that you are a part of. This game takes everything I love about text-based games: character development, relationship development, and eventual story development, and brings it to a perfect compound. Even though it is short, it is that because of the experience. It engages you like a movie, but further grips you in place as the deciding factor; as the mystery unfolds, it is up to you to piece it together properly in your head, up to you to make your choices.

All-in-all it's quite an amazing game. I was in awe of how puzzled it made me, how much it made me think. 10/10 game, I would recommend this game to all my friends to play.

Subsurface Circular is the third Steam game by Mike Bithell, and when I saw it, I immediately bought it without checking the synopsis, as the other two games were absolute gems.
Once more, the story heavily revolves around AI and how they should, or should not, decide over their own fate. This is a recurring theme in the three games, but as it is executed differently everytime, it keeps on being interesting.
Similar to the other games, the music and art are delightful, and the story is very pleasant. Subsurface Circular has different gameplay elements compared to the other games, which offers some new perspective.
I have only two dislikes about the game:
-Apart from the voice announcing at which station the metro is arriving, there is no voice acting, and as it was brilliantly performed in the previous games, I was hoping for more on that.
-The story was quite short, as were the stories in the other two games, but here it felt like it could have been longer.
Apart from these dislikes, the game is quite enjoyable, and definitely worth buying.

38675385.review: Thomas Was Alone is easily one of my favorite games: it's fun and easy on both the ears and the eyes, but more importantly it had a lot of heart. Unfortunately, I can't say I got the same enjoyment out of Volume: it was witty, but it felt lacking in substance--it was trying too hard to repeat the success of Thomas Was Alone but didn't really succeed for me. I consequently approached Subsurface Circular with a certain amount of warines; happily, that wariness was unnecessary. While not quite achieving the greatness of Thomas Was Alone, Subsurface Circular manages to be far more substantial than Volume: it felt genuine and authentic rather than contrived. The story was very compelling. My one (minor) complaint is that David Housden did not do the music, and I felt like the game's music didn't really do it justice. Both visually and thematically, the game benefits from the narrow scope of the setting. The game is quite short, but two endings make it replayable. I highly recommend it.

38137931.review:
As a fan of text adventures, this was a refreshing new take on a genre I enjoy. Simplicity is used to great effect - the setting, characters and visuals focus in on the text itself, which is entirely the point. A novel approach to dialogue options and conversation modifiers, too.

The story is interesting, well written, and easily digestible in a short sitting. It doesn't drag, but it feels substantial regardless of its length.

My only sticking point was that the story seems - aside from a big finish - to be a little more linear than I was hoping for, compared to the nostalgic experiences I'm reminded of while playing. Choices typically appear come full circle, but this doesn't really matter. There are elements to the story progression that are optional, so it's certainly not a dressed-up visual novel, and it definitely feels like engaging gameplay.

The interactive developer commentary unlocked after completing the game is interesting, humorous, and presented quite uniquely within the game in a way that adds useful context. The soundtrack is also a wonderful listen, and I've picked it up multiple times.

38017435.review:
After watching NorthernLion's 'Let's Look At' for Subsurface Circular, I was immediately intrigued by its concept and aesthetic. I didn't even finish the whole video before I stopped it to add the game to my wishlist. I love narrative-based games, so I was waiting for a chance to pick this up and experience it for myself. I finally got to during the Autumn Sale. 

Now that I've played through the whole thing, I have to say that the game was well worth the price I paid! I loved the writing in Thomas Was Alone, despite not having finished it, and the dialogue in Subsurface Circular is just as witty and sharp as it was in TWA. The clean UI and minimal art style sell the idea of a future world, and I really liked the intuitive way of communicating with other characters to solve puzzles (and I don't even like puzzles usually).

I think the story is quite thought provoking as well, and speaks to current anxieties about automation and the future of AI. For such a short game, I'd definitely recommend playing it all in one sitting to get the full experience. It's a linear narrative, for sure, but I think it's a good one. (I also love how the developer commentary is integrated so deeply into the game; I really want to go through the whole thing one more time just to see what Mike Bithell thinks about different aspects of development.)

I only wish there was more voice acting or at least more music playing to break up the quiet humming of the train. The music I [i]did[/i] hear was so good, I wish I could have listened to it more, because at times my eyes started to glaze over when there was too much text on screen and nothing was there to break it up. However, those irks are not enough of a negative to change how I feel about the experience. 

If you have a couple of hours to spare and like text adventures reimagined in a modern context, try it out!

38008261.review:
[b]Yeah, I'm sorry but this is some cringey gameplay right here.[/b] For full transparency, I didn't like either of the other two games from this team, so if you did - take my opinion with a grain of salt. The only thing [i]I assure you[/i] that I'm right about is that the core gameplay mechanic is beat. The mechanic of 'dialogue tree choice exhaustion' is not fun. It hinges on needing a super interesting story which is dangerous because not everyone will be moved equally.

Please note I've played ~50% of this game. I tried to perservere to the end but had to throw the towel in. I found my mind wandering and then [i]reading[/i] dialogue quickly slid into [i]skimming[/i] which quickly lead to me mashing straight through the conversations. 

[i]Essentially, this is a visual novel, and at least the first hour (out of a two hour game) had exactly zero choices to be made.[/i]  You simply engage in dialogue with other robots and choose pre-defined dialogue options. Okay, let's strip away the stylish exterior (which is meaningless, really) and just look at the gameplay first. The core gameplay loop is all too familiar for fans of point-n-clicks:

1. Talk to a person 
2. Exhause all possible dialogue options (generic responses consist of the first choice being 'positive' and the second 'negative' - yeah, you've been here before many times)
3. Find new information
4. Go to next person
5. Rinse and repeat

The cycle was fine decades ago, but we've come a long way baby.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+I guess the stylish graphics/cinematography is nice enough - it does feel paper thin, though.
+Even though I wasn't moved by the universe/setting/story, I have to give credit that at least it was unique.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Even after changing the option, the dialogue was horribly slow.
-Why did it look like they were typing? I'm not sure what it's like to 'link' to a robot, but I would assume we could just 'talk' with no typing delay.
-I hate it when I am roleplaying a character and I actually have to create backstory on-the-fly instead of just 'being born' into the story in this moment, and seeing things from this point forward. Hope that makes sense. Another way to put this is that I don't like to have to choose dialogue options about details of past cases (for example), that I (IRL) have no information about. I did not experience that, so I feel awkward 'making it up'.
-The core mechanic of simply exhausting choices with every NPC is... Well... Exhausting. It's tedious and ho-hum. It's been done so many times before. And it's always a mechanic that's part of a much bigger game. Here, the whole game is this little mechanic.
-The story did not interest me enough. Again, I give credit for something original, but I could care less how it all pans out.
-It's completely linear - no matter what you say (in the first hour, at least) will funnel you to the exact same conclusion you are meant to arrive at.
-Finally, because of the short game length, the devs clearly are concerned with people either just watching a LetsPlay or playing and then refunding, and I get that BUT why not just make it a bigger experience? 

[b]Sorry folks, I cannot recommend this one to my Steam friends.[/b]

37934417.review: This is an excellent, albeit short, text-based game about the uses of AI in society and whether or not they can actually be considered a part of society. Although this subject matter has been explored before, Subsurface Circular shies away from spending too much time waxing philosophical, and rather focuses on a singular sequence of events. The whole game takes place on the titular subway train. You, as an AI detective, have conversations with other AI to investigate the disappearance of a number of AI linked to a certain antagonist. Your job is to uncover the link. You have various key words to use in conversations in order to progress the story and uncover the information you need. It's incredibly engrossing and kept me thinking about the ramifications of my words throughout the game. There is, of course, a decision to be made in the end, and that one had me staring at my options for a few minutes before I made my choice. I wholeheartedly recommend this game, as the only complaint I could muster is that at one point I felt like I got stuck in a conversation loop until I figured out the mechanic that I needed to take advantage of to progress. This is another excellent game by Mike Bithell and is worth the asking price.

37930346.review:
Subsurface? Maybe. Sub-par? Not at all.


Just as I was settling in for a night of Japanese takeout and Overwatch, Thomas Was Alone designer Mike Bithell dropped a surprise release on Steam. So I abandoned my post faster than a Royal Mail employee on a Friday night and grabbed a copy of this robot detective game. Apart from a few sly tweets and whispers in the industry, no one had any idea this game was coming.  

Subsurface Circular is a spins a casual, yet brittle tale of class, religion and power, with undertones of revolution and an ever-present nod towards the old ‘Robots will prevail’ tech dystopia. It tells a story and builds mystery in a single setting by consistently changing its direction, tone and characters, providing a different interaction in every scene. 

Your journey begins, and you, a robot detective, are your help is requested from a worried 
Tek with a missing friend. ‘Tek’, is the term for robots in this game, and there’s lots of different ones, which you’ll meet throughout your train ride. Robots get on and off the train, and it’s your job to talk to each of them, and solve the mystery of the missing Tek. 

The plot juggles themes like AI, conspiracy and human rights, but keeps it light and mostly on surface level as your investigation progresses. Each Tek you talk to requires something from you, be it a phrase, piece of information or the answer to a riddle. Some Teks even work as a pair, and your interaction with one will affect another’s responses. That was clever, Bithell. You smart little thing. 

The fact that your character does not move throughout the entire game, is a testament to the astuteness of the narrative; an entire plot revolves around you, and you don’t even need to leave your seat. The interactions are so well calculated, that I didn’t have a clue what was going on until the carefully placed reveals. Every robot has it’s own thing going on, its dialogue laced with a special wit generally found in the works of team Bithell, and I thoroughly adored the 4th wall-shattering fedora tip towards Thomas Was Alone. 

Subsurface Circular was a glorious little spin of a classic sci-fi concept, that didn’t require a lot of time or commitment to enjoy. It’s design and scripting were spot on, and I was particularly impressed by it’s smooth, sleek UI. That, and I’m still buzzing over the part where I had to emotionally manipulate a pair of robots to retrieve the information I needed. Subsurface Circular is a canny, resourceful little release, and I hope team Bithell have similar ideas in the bank, because this one was lovely.

36678995.review:
A stylish short text adventure, like a Twine with a well crafted visual environment and UI. It touches on some interesting and thought provoking themes. In that respect, it's kind of like My Dinner With Andre only on a subway car instead of a restaurant. With robots.
OK, maybe not at all like that, but this game does give you some serious food for thought, as well as being an interesting and well written mystery with some unexpected turns.

There is a bit of replayability, too, mostly because the Game+ mode adds some interesting developer commentary, in the form of an additional robot you can question during gameplay (which is a pretty clever way of doing it). You can ask the robot lots of questions about the design process, art direction, themes, dialogue, etc. and it's almost feels like doing an AMA with Mike Bithell. If you're interested at all in game design, and about the themes written into this and why it was created, that's kind of a great bonus.
You can also replay to see the differences in how you approach each encounter, and the result of your choices, but that's relatively minor, as there aren't a billion different endings or achievements (thank god).

Well worth checking out at the paltry price they're asking for it.

The game offers very little in terms of action; players are restricted to conversational choices, and some interesting puzzles, but it is more narrative than game.

If you are interested in a good cyberpunk/noir story with interesting characters and premise, I would highly recommend Subsurface Circular.

Week 31
30/52
Subsurface Circular
Platform: PC
Time: ~2 hours
Genre: Indie, robot, text-based, adventure

Someone recommended subsurface circular to me - And if he didn't, I would never have noticed this game.
I'm normally avoiding anything that looks "too robotic" or "too scifi" (There are a few good exceptions tho) - So this game would never catch my eye, anywhere. 

Subsurface Circular is a game from the same developer who made Thomas Was Alone (Which are a great game, you should try or look up if you don't already have). 
In SC you are a "teks" (Robot) detective who are looking for answers. While trying to do "your job" talking to everyone, you learn about the universe around you. 
Quickly you learn that something is completely off, and you try to figure out what. 
The game is simple, interesting and truly beautiful. 

There is - obviously - a lot of reading involved, but it's a very nice story, and I felt connected to it pretty fast. It even had some good references to Thomas was alone.
The game has a few small puzzles as well (Wouldn't mind a few more), which works great for the game, and are integrated nicely. 

I like the simple style of the game, but would love some added features - That make you feel more like the character. 
Maybe something like a posing or hand gesture option. Nothing game changing, but it could be pretty neat. It's such a pretty game, and I wish I could explore its visuals more.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

Subsurface Circular is a text adventure game developed and published by Mike Bithell or his company known as Bithell Games, the same company behind the amazing Thomas Was Alone and Volume. While some people may be turned off by a text adventure game where you don't really do anything but select a few choice here and there and see the outcome, I think that with Subsurface Circular, it allowed Mike Bithell to write engaging stories, beautiful and heartfelt stories

Everything from the writing, to the concept behind robotics and the human race in the possible near future, the UI and the sound design are all spot-on. If you like the concept of a future where robots and humans work hand in hand to provide a sustainable future and what happens when power is left in the wrong hands, then this is the game for you!

Subsurface Circular is a short sci-fi story about the role of robots in a near future society where robots coexist with humans, how they take the jobs of humans, how humans cope with robots around them. It's about people, and robots-who-are-people, and where society's going with the idea

It is presented in a very pleasant style. The choices are interesting, the focus system is interesting, and you can manipulate your fellow robots as you try to get to the bottom of a simple missing person case

Although short and only took me roughly an hour and a half, within that hour and a half I was more drawn into the story and what was trying to be conveyed then playing a 15 hour campaign where the story is not even as well written and explained as Subsurface Circular

36438943.review:
The writing is excellent, as is to be expected from Blithell. It doesn't outstay its welcome and is the right price for what you get.

The game takes place entirely in a single carriage on a circular metro line. You are a robot detective, interviewing your fellow passengers to figure out why other robots are disappearing. This is a great concept, and I love short stories that take place entirely in one setting. 

However, the game does seem to think that interviewing randomers who happen to use your carriage is a good substitute for, like, methodical investigation. A robot on my train would pass on a third-hand rumour and it would say, "Ooh, you found out something useful there!"

Additionally, the callback to "Thomas Was Alone" was really awkwardly wedged in there.

But these criticisms are minor compared to this single point in the game's favour: at one point, the game actually made me get up and find some scrap paper, write out a logic table, and solve it. Brilliant. Worth it for that alone.

36433180.review:
An interesting concept that doesn't overstay its welcome, and a mystery with a satisfying conclusion and clever twist. There are a few puzzles that feel like they were included because someone thought there needed to be a "game" there, and I think they're to the detriment of the narrative - the real reason to play this game is for the writing. If you enjoyed the SNES Shadowrun or TES3:Morrowind's "keyword" dialogue systems, you'll feel right at home here. To some extent, this isn't a kind of game you can recommend to friends you play games with. It's not a game meant to be shared in the modern sense like MMORPGs, Mobas, mmoFPS, arena shooters and alike. It's more like a book you enjoy for yourself more than for some sort of auxiliary entertainment that comes from satisfying mechanics or epic visuals.

In its base, Subsurface Circular is a very small window into a very complex and almost organic society that feels familiar but is distant enough to enjoy without much background. To the visual novel reader, the sort of engaging text options will feel familiar, but as opposed to directing a story and wooing other characters, it's more of a service to fill you in this potrayal of a life when stripped down to its core, but then jammed into the struggling everyman. If anything, the main protagonist is our gate to a world that I desparately wish could be traversed and explored.

The only downside is its length, which varies by reading speeding, yet it's its own experience. Half the price of a movie, but double the level of immersion and story-telling than the majority of them.

5/5 game for me.

36281361.review:
Everything from the writing, to the ideas, to the UI, to the sound design is spot-on. One of the most polished IF titles I've ever played. If the concept seems appealing to you, please, please buy it. It's very good.

But just in case you're not willing to buy a sci-fi interactive fiction game without some more words: it's essentially a short sci-fi story about the role of robots in a near-future society. It's about how robots coexist with humans, how they take the jobs of humans, how humans cope with robots around them. It's about people, and robots-who-are-people, and where society's going.

It's a lot to think about, presented in a very pleasant style. The choices are interesting, the focus system is interesting, and you can manipulate your fellow robots as you try to get to the bottom of a missing persons case.

It took me roughly two hours of reading to get all of the achievements and both endings, and I'm very happy to experience it.

Long story short: enjoy this! Support the dev so they make more like this! Enjoy how charming the robots are!

Mike Bithell has always been a fascinating developer for me. Thomas Was Alone was a great example of how putting a bit of context to an simple platforming game could make it feel like so much more.

Subsurface Circular is very similar in that aspect. It's a basic text adventure where you play as a detective tasked with solving a disappearance case that is not what it seems. I don't want to spoil anything here, but the writing here is on par with his previous games. There's a captivating story here, with little twists and turns that keep it from feeling like your typical sci-fi story.

If you're interested in seeing an Asmov-inspired sci-fi narrative unfold with your choices adding an interesting depth to the mix, you won't want to miss this. Absolutely worth the time and money I spent on it.

36039454.review:
I recommend this game, I really do. Because honestly, there is no real reason to not buy and play it: it's cheap ([b]buy[/b]) and short ([b]play[/b]). Of course, this doesn't mean that [i]every[/i] short and cheap game deserves a recommendation (but most do, because "what do you have to lose?")
So let me talk briefly about why and how this game is different from other cheap-and-short games: (fair warning though: if you are of the "is this a game?!" crowd that can't enjoy things without higher authorities placing labels on them, you may be disappointed because "this is NOT a game!")
Here we have a stageplay where script is basically a choose-your-own-scenario book. We have "exit stage left"s and "transition"s and all. Hell, we even have an application of Chekov's gun! [spoiler] You'll get that joke later. [/spoiler] Is it a good play? Sure, not like I see androids walking around asking for directions everyday! But is it a [i]great[/i] play? Not really, but that's okay. This is Bithell Games' first experiment with short games and a different narrative method, I'll give them the benefit of doubt and look forward to their next attempt. What is wrong with the script? Well, that is not what this review deals with, I may (or may not) share it on game's discussion board, or you may simply buy the game, play for 2 hours and evaluate for yourself. I did recommend the game, did I not?

36038643.review: Too short. I Wish it was a full on detective game with cases, but it is great for what it is an aestheticly pleasing text based mystery that will keep you asking questions until the end (or me anyway).

36033412.review: Occasionally a game provides me with such an incredible personal experience that I want to share it and recommend it. Subsurface Circular just did exactly that. I bought it and played it through - which took about 90 minutes, including a couple of quick interruptions - and I could not put it down until I completed the story. This is an interactive novel of the highest calibre. The puzzles the game presents are excellent and well thought-through, the writing is tonally spot-on and characterful, and the visuals that accompany it all give you enough of an atmosphere that the story can focus on being a story, and not on exposition. Add to this an excellent soundscape, and everything in this game does exactly no more than it needs to in order to service the story and the discovery, and in today's AAA culture that is a very undervalued trait. I cannot recommend this game enough, and I look forward to experiencing the differences the next time I play.

35976672.review:
Subsurface Circular is a cross between a choose-your-own-adventure book, a text adventure and a mystery novel.    You take the part of a 'detective' on the underground, where you are presented with a mystery to solve.   You can chat to other commuters on the subway to ask them about the investigation.  Some you can also do little favours for. 

The wonderful thing about the game is that it explores (tangentially) the ultimate goal of robotics and AI:  Once we can make bots which are as good as us, what role will /they/ want in the partnership?   Will we end up being surpassed?  

The dialog tree is a set of constrained choices, not free-form.  Other than the tannoy announcements, everything is purely text-based.   This meshes nicely with the idea that the 'bots are communicating over a private chat channel, like IM.   It also means that you can imprint your own voices and feelings onto the 'bots themselves.  

The game is minimalistic, insofar as there's one location (a train carriage), and one type of person to talk to (bots).  The bots have some morphological variation, but are all built along the same lines.  They all sit, move, and talk differently. They all have different 'buttons' you can push to elicit different responses.   For the most part what you choose doesn't affect things too much, but in some (restricted) cases, you can earn an achievement or two by being persistent or following a humorous avenue of dialog.   

It lasts about 2 to 3 hours.  The pace can be changed, but it's a relaxing "sit back and enjoy the story" kind of game, so the default speed feels about right.   The graphics are lovely, with great use of motion, lighting, texturing and depth blurring.    The 'bots all move in a convincing 'bottish' way, and they all feel solid'.

Overall, I really enjoyed Subsurface Circular.  It was highly relaxing, thought-provoking, and gave just enough humour to give a wry smile from time to time.   There are a few times when the setup seems a tad obvious (e.g. in one part a bot needs another type of bot, and lo and behold that exact bot type happens to also sit down at the same time).  Doing this gave a little mini-game, but broke the flow a little by the coincidence.   Of course, perhaps it was a forced coincidence? I dunno. That's too many levels of indirect thinking for me at this time of night.

I paid about £4 for it, and that feels about right for something of this length.  If it's on sale any cheaper it'd be a steal, grab it! :)

I never came around to playing it again with Dev Commentary, but this "after finishing the game" feature really interests me. It took me ~2 hours to "beat it", judging from achievements I managed to miss one interaction.

WHAT YOU SHOULD EXPECT?
Expect engaging in a short SF story, a classic open ended one like 70s and 80s classic but with more modern themes and writing. There are some really dark themes there, so be wary of that, unless you don't consider robots people. 

What's interesting here is that we interact with robots and their perception of future of our society, but those are not human clad in robot skins. They seem to react, think and behave in a way that seems like a honest attempt at depicting robots and not humanising them.

The one feature I miss is ability to view in game the opening cinematic with ability to pause and rewind after finishing the game. I ponder how much of the plot is signaled there but it goes a tadbit fast for me to be sure.

Highly recommend

PS.
Almost must play if you work in gamedev. There are some neat experiments within the mechanics. It's not the greatest game or story of all time, but it has a lot of value compared to the price and I'm glad that I got to experience it.

35759839.review:
[b]Subsurface Circular[/b] is rather one of the few of its kind than unique. It's a modern text adventure that are quite few these days. Nevermind that it is short - it offers more than some games can offer, and it's better when completed in one sit. In addition to that, the price is fair compared to the length of the game.

[b]PLEASE DON'T REFUND.[/b] The game's short lasting doesn't mean you can just easily throw it away after playing. Be a judge to yourself - if you enjoyed the story, don't mind paying for it. The price of the game is not small, and it won't be a hard hit to your pocket.

[b]THE MAIN INGREDIENT.[/b] Intriguing detective story, gritty setting, sundry characters, satisfying atmosphere. Feelings you get from 'talking' to wordless androids that seem so alive, and listening to their complaints. Feelings you get when you resolve them. It's beautiful this way. Not exactly the most exciting gameplay - it is, still, a text adventure. Still beautiful.

[b]Subsurface Circular[/b] resembles the movies of the past by its lore and setting. [strike]After some time[/strike] At a moment's notice you'll find yourself immersed into the game; you'll feel the somberness around you, not just in front of you. The whole design thing here is quite well crafted, being unique in some ways and quite aspiring. The visuals are very pleasing; the metro system feels so lovely, man, so good.

[b]Overall[/b] it is a great experience, alas short. Although, you wouldn't be needing more - the story ends right where it should. Give it a go. Happy riding!

35745027.review:
A delightful visual novel taking place on the underground train service of a future city. As a detective robot you decide to go against your programming and take on a case given to you by a stranger in a panic, and not one given to you by the government. So starts your circular adventure as you try and unravel the mysteries that lurk below the surface in this city rife with robots. Will you solve the mystery?

PROS:
+ Hot robots! - Oh boy do I like some attractive robots and this game has more attracive robots than you could shake a stick of RAM at. The designs of the robots are delightful and varied.
+ Would you look at that writing! - There's lots of reading afoot and the words are good! Subsurface Circular has great writing and dances with ideas that will, hopefully, leave you thinking and constantly wondering about the robots to come.
+ Are the robots real? - The characters you come across are great and I really enjoyed talking to them, well, not talking.... forming a wireless connection with them. Robot stuff.

CONS:
- Is it a puzzle? - There's not much actual puzzling afoot as you sit down and ride the train. For the most part you do just read through the conversations and give them varying prompts of information that you have learned about previously. To be fair I wouldn't really call this a negative because there's still a sense of achievement to be gained from prompting robots with questions to get what little bit of information they may have and then running off (in a metaphorical sense, you're very much sat down) and talk to the next attractive robot. So, this really doesn't count as a negative, but I guess some people may be expecting a bit more than a visual novel with a greater level of interaction than your average VN.
- Help I can't stop thinking about it! - It's been months and I'm still sometimes finding myself thinking about this game. Did I make the right choice? What does it mean for our society in real life? Do I have an odd attraction to actual robots? I can't sleep at night as these haunt me, which probably is a bit of a con because it's ruined my life, but in a good way.

Overall Subsurface Circular is a delightfully small game that you can knock out in an afternoon and it's definitely worth it. An enrapturing tale that'll hopefully leaving you chomping at the ... CPU (that's a robot thing?) to continue to the bottom of this case.

(MORE THOUGHTS [url=https://mozillogames.wordpress.com/2017/09/11/subjugating-crime-in-subsurface-circular/]HERE[/url]

This is a very simple game far as game-play as it is all dialogue driven. But, don't let that fool you. It is a very intelligent game, where the player is pulled into a conspiracy that is bigger than they could imagine; all from the seat of a subway.

The music is simple, yet elegant and fits the theme very well ... 

The graphics, again; clean and polished yet not overdone with unneeded eye candy. Perfect for robots sitting in a subway car engaging in conversation.

The game is a bit existential and maybe even a bit political as some dialogue touches on subjects of "doing jobs other won't", "racism", etc. While none of this was overly preachy nor too slanted towards one ideology or the other; there is an overall feeling of a more liberal approach to it. Just to be honest. But, this does not affect the game's choices nor is the protagonist just a droning puppet to make a political point.

35432164.review:
Entre Stories Untold y Subsurface Circular en 2017 tenemos dos grandísimas aventuras basadas en texto que recuperan una narrativa ya en desuso y la reinventan con las opciones que da el medio como videojuego hoy en día. A su vez son rarezas y pese a lo pretenciosos que puedan ser estos juegos son necesarios pese al poco público que recoge. 

Pero entrando en materia, la narrativa de Subsurface Circular es más simple que en Stories Untold (y no por ello mala), su núcleo se basa en conversaciones, en pregunta y respuesta pero conforme avanzas se vuelve todo más enrevesado e inclusivo los últimos capítulos un puzzle. La fuerza reside en lo que trata, leyes de Asimov, sociología y que adoptamos como personalidad, la razón de ser y que nos hace ser, la decadencia humana y el error de escurrir la culpabilidad de nuestros problemas. El lado moral de las conversaciones también es algo a destacar, pues desde poder llevar la conversación de una forma cordial, también podemos comportarnos como unos completos cretinos. 

Es un juego ameno, casi anecdótico en este medio. Pero necesario si queremos definir todas las ramas de la narrativa que nos ofrece. Altamente recomendable a los que van en buscar de rarezas, aceptando su único impedimento, el idioma.

35350310.review:
Subsurface Circular is a small game that can only really be given a short review. But luckily, the game still makes a fresh change of pace from most games on the market. As a visual novel or rather, text based adventure, it certainly delivers.

You play as a Tek Dectective, a smart robot on the underground train on the Subsurface Circular line of a city. You are soon brought into an investigation to try and discover a truth.

I won't spoil you on the details, but it is a facinating and thoughtful story which makes you stop and think about what is actually happening in the world this game portrays, with little mentions of the other works the devolopers made, leading to a decision which you will be struggling to make a decision on.

As you play through the game, you will find yourself solving puzzles which may prove tricky at first, but there is normally a logical and clever way of sorting them out, making them very rewarding to do.

Now, the game is short, and is meant to be played in a single sitting. But I do believe that you will get your moneys worth. Now, if you don't like text based adventures or visual novels, then don't get this game. But for those who want something a little bit different or like such games, you will certainly enjoy this one.

35263635.review: Excellent VN futuriste à la direction artistique léchée et un univers intéressant que le jeu vous laisse imaginer à travers vos différentes discussions.

35247537.review:
A nice little story, wrapped up in about 2h30min.
Another hour if you care for the dev commentary or want to exhaust the "listener"s discussion trees.
Gameplay is pretty simple (select discussion paths), and there's a couple of puzzles to solve along the way (there's a "hint" button in case you're stuck on a puzzle, didn't try it though).
The story itself explores some pretty conventional "robot future" possibilities, but it's the way you uncover the world by talking to the passengers, without ever leaving the train, which gives it its charm. There's some interesting, tought-provoking decisions to take towards the ends, with a good ending that wrap itself up nicely.

	[td][b][i]Subsurface Circular[/i][/b] is a well crafted little text adventure by Mike Bithell that touches on some interesting topics such the rise of artificial intelligence to how mankind is rapidly automating what it can, to the fear of where humankind will fit within this rapidly transforming landscape. Bithell uses these topics as a springboard into a mystery about a robot detective investigating other missing robots on an underground rail transit system. It is a simple but engaging experience that is thankfully very well written with a central mystery that is worth your time spent trying to solve.[/td]

35110321.review:
This is the exact kind of game I'm down with playing these days: Cheap, thoughtful, and relatively short in a way that suggests they didn't feel the need to pad out the length with reiterations of the same gameplay concepts.

In some ways, it's the opposite of Bithell's earlier work, Thomas Was Alone, since this game has almost no voicework, but also uses conversation as a mechanic, something the player had no control over in the TWA.

Games like this live or die on the strength of the writing, and Subsurface Circular succeeds remarkably well on this front. There wasn't a single conversation I found tedious, every character revealed some new aspect of this future robot culture. It seems to follow the basic concept that if a mechanic or a concept doesn't advance the story or provide something interesting, just cut it out.

I would love it if people like Bithell kept putting out these sort of games, it's a satisfying use of my time.

35084527.review:
Subsurface Circular plays for me like the videogame equivalent of the best 'bottle episodes', or narratives given the theatrical restriction of one setting to really focus on and amplify smaller details of the writing. A self-proclaimed 'Bithell Short', SC's formal restrictions (dialogue tree-driven, mouse click short form narrative) and writerly restraint (it takes place entirely on the eponymous underground train system transporting robots to various locations on the surface that we only hear about in conversation) free it of the wide burden and bloat that can afflict even the best open world games of larger scale. It hits a goldilocks zone for me of not too committal, not too complexly-interfaced, and not overwhelming (exploration is possible, but within the comforting corridors of conversation, not vast vistas or sprawling streets). You don't often see the short form in video games, and I appreciated being able to play this one through in one sitting if I wanted, or pick it up in bits and pieces when not afforded an abundance of play time. 
I also enjoy the story, and would love to keep seeing what has already been a trend this year of sci fi video games tackling genre tread territory with the fresh perspective of contemporary angles and issues. SC is set in a world in which labor has been automated, and that hasn't ushered in a post-scarcity utopia so much as created a new underclass of sentient machines targeted by neo-Luddite hate groups. You are one of these robots, a model relegated to the task of detective and investigating a series of robot disappearances. I shouldn't say any more for fear of spoilers, but I found the narrative engaging, at points surprising, and always with a range of tonality that is absolutely charming. 
If you're into narrative driven games and futurist sci-fi, definitely check this out.

35037231.review:
This is not the type of game I would normally purchase. I enjoy mechanically intensive games almost exclusively. I purchased this game on a whim and am very happy I did so. The game took me about an hour and forty minutes to complete but it felt like no time at all. The game is engaging, the story is deep, and it touches on so many aspects of culture and society.

It's a game that entirely features robots, and you never leave where you are. Despite this, the game manages to discuss immigration, racism, slavery, human (and non-human) rights, and so much more. The game does not tell you what to think of these issues, rather it presents you with a society that contains these issues and lets you make of it what you will.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone and everyone. It will surprise you and leave you satisfied in so many ways.

34852169.review:
Subsurface Circular is fundamentally a text-based story game where you play as a robot detective, and the graphics, dialog, and premise itself build an awesome environment for those text conversations to take place in. It is not a long game (~2 hours plus a bit more cleaning up achievements), but it is a good one. I had massive expectations for the game as it is from the same team as the gem Thomas Was Alone, perhaps unrealistically high, so while I was a little let down by the fact that I wasn't sucked into the game, I did really enjoy it in the end. There are 2 (I don't think there's any other than 2) puzzles in the game which are suprising difficult for being seemingly a very small part of the game, but there is a built-in aid to solve them which does help, and they should be solvable by pretty much any player.

Gameplay takes place as text-based conversations with other robots on a train where your dialoge is choosen from a set of options you're given each time it is your turn to speak. You talk to a variety of robots from a variety of occupations, and the game does a great job painting a world and making each conversation seem unique. The game takes place as a 3D render of the robots as they sit on, enter, and exit the train which makes the game feel much more full than if it were simply the text. The rendering is nice and the intro scene is really neat. The music that plays is choosen well, but is mostly background. The story is interesting (as you would hope from a story-driven detective game), but not overwhelmingly so, and up until the end I would have had few qualms about getting up and taking a break if I had needed too, contrary to a game like OneShot that keeps you wanting to play more and more in the same sitting.

In terms of achievements, most are tied to progression and will be awarded in a single playthrough, and the others can be gotten in a few minutes by going back and replaying specific parts of specific scenes (you can choose to replay specific portions of the game once you've beaten it). A few may not be immidiately obvious as to how they are earned, but there are discussions on the game's Steam forum to help you figure it out.

I guess the purpose of reviews is to help you answer the question: Should I buy this game? And I think the answer in this case is, yes, you should play through this game. However if you aren't super intrigued by the game's style, perhaps you should wait for a sale as it is on the short side, so the price may be a tad steep in some people's eyes.



A Note (Mild Spoiler): After playing through this game I played back through Thomas Was Alone, and I really like how this game made subtle references to it. I think that did improve my opinion of this game, as they reference it in a very clever way that makes a lot of sense, and if you haven't played Thomas Was Alone, give it a go. It is wonderful.

This is my type of game, but it is admittably not for everyone. You are paying $6 (ish) to read a story. You don't move - the only "action" is choosing different dialogue options. (And those dialogue options have minimal impact on the story). 

You are an "Asimov-ian" robot detective in the future. You are sitting on a train, investigating some disappearances. You will talk about humans, but never see one. You will interview the other commuters on that train. I'm not a fan of noir, but I thought the story was good enough, and it came together at the end in a satisfying way. And it's 1-2 hour play time was perfect. 

A note: I played this in early Sepetember 2017 on a decent MSI laptop with a GTX 1070 and 1080p GSync monitor. When I started the game  the first time, the resolution settings worked as expected. When I took a break after 30 minutes and restarted, I could not get the resolution set properly. The game was absolutely playable, but the game was stretched out into an ultra-widescreen view, with black bars on the top and bottom. In this style of game, it is not a big deal, but it deserves note.

Never has the phrase "short but sweet" been more true than in this great little game! The premise, as you may have gathered from the trailers, is that you´re a robot (Tek) detective that decides to uncover the mistery behind the disappearance of a robot, all while being unable to leave the Subsurface Circular, an underground line. Throughout the game, you meet and interrogate different robot commuters, who all have different personalities and quirks, while solving an intriguing and well crafted story. This game is mostly played through dialogue choices, but they´re implemented in quite an original way, creating engaging, and entertaining puzzles, that can even get quite complex. But, if you´re in it just for the story, (which is completely understandable) you can make use of both a Hint and Automated Deduction systems, which ease and skip the puzzles respectively. 
All in all, it is a great game, that knows very well how to make use of its limited runtime. 9/10 EXTREMELY RECOMMENDED!!

34744328.review:
[h1]Video Review[/h1]

https://youtu.be/pr9_36So7zs

[h1]Quick Info[/h1]

[i]Subsurface Circular[/i] is a game that could have been far more interesting than it turned out to be. As it is, it is a simple visual novel that ends up being an interesting, but not exceptional, read with poor gameplay. The visuals are almost completely meaningless, with most entities the player interacts with not moving at all throughout their conversations. The story clearly pulls heavily from Asimov’s works with an emphasis on seeing the rise of artificial intelligence from the A.I.’s perspective. However, in terms of gaming narratives this one is fairly simple given that the majority of the player’s actions have little to no effect on the outcome. If you’re looking for a quick, and rather light, read then this may well be the game for you. Outside of that, [i]Subsurface Circular[/i] ended up being rather disappointing from both a narrative and gameplay perspective.

For more info see the video above or read the review at: [url=https://vinrafel.blogspot.com/2017/09/review-subsurface-circular.html]Vinrafel[/url]

34675379.review:
[h1] A noir story on a train [/h1]
Subsurface Circular puts you into the mind of a detective robot in a world you can only glean about by investigating robot passengers on a train. 

What sounds like an excellent concept for a game could turn out being very hard. For example, the game could be too linear, being more of a book because the developers didn't have the skill/time to implement a world but are so proud of it then over inform you or force you to do the old "rub every noun against every source of information until the game is beat" type gameplay. SC ignores both options and forges ahead, writing a tale worthy of Asimov but giving you characters you care about and a narrative filled with choices.


[h1] That's a mouthful. If it's a game, how's it look and sound? [/h1]

While sound is minimal, it's well implemented. From the train calling out your stations to the ambient noise, there's plenty of sound going on. Graphically the game isn't anything you'll call home about. The simple meshes work well for the visuals provided, but the texture resolution and lighting won't have you pulling the game out as a benchmark. Nor should it, given the relatively low price point for entertainment value. The game runs about 2 hours per playthrough and as far as I can tell has three endings to get you to that amount of playtime.


[h1] So it's good then? [/h1]

This game is [i]excellent[/i] in terms of narrative and one that I highly recommend for anyone even slightly interested. The mood and tone are set early on and survives the entire game. The story is so good, I'm going to be completing those as well, just to see the other endings. I recommend the game if you're even a little interested in story based games or if you're looking for something really good and really different.

A short review for a short but enjoyable game:

Great writing and unexpected twists make for a good but brief experience with Subsurface Circular. You embark on an underground train talking to many different "Teks", Learning about them, trying to gage their personality and it all comes to a fantastically well done choice at the end that actually is somewhat effected by your choices. It is a shame how short it is though as I feel these characters and this scenario could have been better fleshed out but it does its job and I enjoyed my short time with this game. Un superbe petit jeu qui fait exactement son taff (Raconter une histoire intéressante) pour le prix.

Pendant 2 heures, on vit une aventure textuelle entièrement en anglais (er...) où l'intérêt n'est pas de plier l'histoire à notre volonté et de faire des choix artificiels, mais plutôt de jouer un personnage, notre personnage. Notons quelques petites énigmes bien dosées et fort chouettes demandant de sortir le papier et le crayon ce qui est franchement cool !

La présentation est lêchée comme une belle démo Unity (c'est un compliment) tandis que les personnages rencontrés sont tous intéressants, profonds et amènent peu à peu au joueur des blocs lui permettant de comprendre cet univers étrange dans lequel il est propulsé.

Enfin, je conclurai sur la fin. Réflexion, responsabilité, croyances personnelles, tout vous sera demandé pour ces derniers instants qui feront que l'aventure restera dans votre tête pendant quelques nuits.

Bref, merci Monsieur Bithell, moi je retourne jouer à Thomas Was Alone ;)

34548204.review:
Fair warning; all you really do in this game is read unvoiced dialog, make dialog choices, and solve the occasional word/logic puzzle. However, the compulsion involved is one of mystery. Beating around the bush, nipping at clues, catching the odd 'Red' herring (inside joke), and still not getting the full scope until the very end.

Ultimately I enjoyed the totality of my experience with the game. I will make one complaint that the "ending" is two binary extremes. However, you can still infer your own contextual conclusion to your A or B choice.

Narratively the game explores the beaten path that is automation taking over our general work-force. Something that's been tackled many times since the first major automation boom in the 80's. It also mixes in the implications of true AI of various complexities having taken over such general labor, and even specialized work. You are a Detective AI Tek(robot), and you find yourself investigating not only the main plot, but also the subset context of the world itself. Bound to a subway train for the entirety of the experience.

I hate movies that are confined to singular spaces or relatively small locations, and yet I didn't dislike this game confining me to a single seat on a subway train car. Because the frequent delivery of world-building kept my mind's eye imagining the world outside. This made a 'world' of difference.

The only kind of person I can see not enjoying the experience this has to offer is a self-absorbed, conceited, narcissist.
The game costs less than a typical meal for one person, and lasts longer. No cost/hour excuses allowed.

34545467.review:
I got a good couple hours of gameplay out of it and I feel like it's worth the price despite its length. Both the plot and the game aesthetic kept me hooked during the entirety of the experience. It's not very sophisticated in terms of puzzles or real detective work (at least not to the degree that some other detective-oriented games like Darkness Within are) but in this case it serves to give you a good sense of accomplishment without having any moments that drag on. It's very streamlined in how the story unfolds and though it is rather linear, you have the option of pursuing different lines of inquiry as you please. Your choices feel weighty and do carry consequences.

Overally, definitely fun and intriguing. I would like to see more games of this kind.

34539980.review:
Développé par Bithell Games a qui l'on doit les excellents Volume et Thomas was Alone, Subsurface Circular est une sorte d'ovni vidéo ludique dans sa forme et dans sa façon de sortir par le simple biais d'un tweet. En effet, exit les plans marketing et autres publicités, accueillons une sortie impromptue et volontairement limitée. On incarne donc un robot détective dénommé Claire qui va devoir mener une enquête bien étrange sur la disparition de l'ami d'un autre robot. Pour ce faire, on va traverser toute la ville dans le métro et y interroger des habitants robots grâce à un astucieux système de dialogue et de découvertes à creuser.

Subsurface Circular s'apparente à un jeu d'enquête dans lequel on va devoir découvrir ce qui est arrivé à plusieurs robots disparus dans un univers futuriste où les humains et les robots cohabitent paisiblement ou presque. Le jeu est simple mais rudement efficace, on se déplace automatiquement de station de métro en station de métro et l'on fera connaissance de différents robots qu'il faudra interroger afin de découvrir des indices et autres pistes. Chaque découverte du puzzle nous octroiera une nouvelle possibilité de dialogue et d'interrogation, il conviendra alors de poser de nouvelles questions aux robots qui n'avaient plus rien à nous dire jusque là. C'est donc un véritable travail d'enquêteur qui nous attend avec également quelques énigmes plutôt corsées afin de débloquer des situations ubuesques.

Un poil court mais pas en terme d'idées.
Subsurface Circular est un jeu vraiment attachant que ce soit au niveau de son histoire dense et intéressante qu'au niveau de ses protagonistes. Sans jamais rencontrer d'humains, on va vite se rendre compte que tout n'est pas rose entre les robots et les hommes. On s'attache aux différentes personnalités et aux étranges possibilités que nous apporte la vie de robot d'usine, lover, publicitaire ou policier à l'humeur changeante. D'un ton résolument mature, l'histoire est plutôt complexe et il faudra parfois se faire violence pour ne pas accélérer le texte tant il y a d'informations à retenir. Les différentes phases de jeu reprennent des épisodes avec le même décor mais de tous nouveaux robots à rencontrer et à faire cracher leurs ci-boulons afin qu'ils nous aident à progresser dans l'aventure. Le jeu est assez simple malgré tout avec une durée de vie d'environ 3 heures pour peu que l'on tente de tout élucider et d'explorer les différentes fins qui s'offrent à nous.

Le jeu est intégralement en anglais et dans un langage soutenu ce qui risque de poser problème à la plupart des joueurs français. Sachez tout de même que l'on comprend assez bien ce qu'il se passe même si on zappe parfois des dialogues. Le gameplay est assez simple pour que l'on tente plusieurs combinaisons de dialogue afin de découvrir un indice et ainsi d'obtenir une aide nous indiquant où nous devons concentrer nos recherches. Certaines énigmes nécessiteront également du papier et un stylo pour trouver les bonnes réponses à certaines questions mais aussi pour comprendre un robot déglinguer. C'est drôle et rarement frustrant, on s'amuse comme dans les grands jeux d'aventure de l'époque à tout noter à l'instar des excellents Zork par exemple. La réalisation est impeccable avec un excellent travail sur le design et quelques effets plutôt réussi dans le métro. Rien de bien folichon mais le résultat est unique et propre. Même une petite configuration pourra faire tourner le jeu sans le moindre problème. Mention spéciale à la bande son réalisée par dan le sac.

Reboot
Subsurface Circular est donc une expérience courte mais ô combien intéressante. Rajoutez également à l'équation un descriptif de la genèse des anciens jeux de Mike Bithell par le biais d'une conversion avec un robot prêtre et vous obtenez un des jeux les plus originaux de cette année 2017. Il est fort recommandé de jouer au jeu en une seule fois car on a très vite fait d'oublier certains détails après quelques jours. Vendu à tout petit prix, il doit surtout être considéré comme une aventure à l'ancienne enrobé de beaux effets et d'un système de mots clés (indices) fort novateur. Le casting des robots est vraiment excellent avec un côté geek très appuyé et une possibilité très pratique de rebooter certains robots.

Difficile donc de rester de marbre devant tant d'intelligence artificielle autonome et devant un avenir si proche et si réel. Tout aussi divertissant soit le jeu, il nous fait nous poser de réelles questions sur l'avancée de l'IA et sur notre future relation avec des robots toujours plus intelligents et plus aptes à prendre eux-mêmes des décisions. Loin de singer les autres histoires d'anticipation, Subsurface Circular décline sa vision et il ne nous prend pas pour des imbéciles dans son dénouement. C'est donc sous le charme de cette aventure robotique que je vous invite à découvrir de toute urgence pour peu que vous aimiez les jeux histoires interactives qui vont bien plus loin que prévu.

34499646.review:
Subsurface Circular is a short text based adventure that feature some interesting dialog and a few riddles.

You play as a detective android (called a Tek) on a mission to find some missing Teks by sitting in the train talking to other Teks.
There are some interesting dialog options that really give the sense that you are talking to a race of machines. Topics like the purpose of existing, machine rights and even religion are addressed in the story.

There was a moment in the game where a Tek mentioned it knew a human joke, but I didn't ask for it again. Only for the next passenger on the train wanting to hear one and having to find another passenger that accidentitly has one.
The game has some of these moments that add to the replayability.

Visually not a lot happens, as it features robots going on and off the train, sitting in seats opposite or besides you but the ever looming train map makes you worried if you still will have the chance to speak to that one robot before the next stop arives. 
However, the visuals and sounds really add to the atmosphere.

At the end the game, [spoiler]it leaves you with a moral choice in which there is no true awnser and it's refreshing to see the moral dilemma's not being painted in black and white[/spoiler].

The game might be a tough sell though. If you are interested in the themes I think you will find this worth your money, but if they aren't your [i]forte[/i] I could give this one a pass.

I think, perhaps, many of these (quite good) story based games are due to their stength in story, and rely more on the recommendation then a telling of what the synopsis is. In fact, if you're as much of an AI science fiction junkie as I, you might catch on pretty quick. But even if you do, the game will still surprise you. It will make you laugh and gasp and pause and think because there are questions you can't answer, decisions you can't make, silly or monumental. 34472533.review:
I bought this game because I played Thomas Was Alone on the Playstation a few years ago, and somehow cried over a bunch of platforming pixels. 

Tonight I finished up this game, after buying it a few days ago; and I speak with no hyperbole when I say that these developers bring about a refreshing burst of emotion and connection in video games, one I've personally been missing. While Subsurface is a short game, it still manages to immediately engage me: the interface is sleek and neat, the dialogue is hilarious; and the story was not just thought-provoking, but interesting. I found myself genuinely gripped at the end game, faced with a decision I could not make easily. For barely $5, this game provided me with such a fun, immersive experience that I want to tell everyone I know, "Hey! Take two hours out of your day and just give this a go, it's worth the time." 

So, give this game a shot, if you've got the money and free time to spare. This game has found a similarly special place in my heart, next to Thomas Was Alone.

This text-conversation-based detective narrative adventure set in a single location starts off fairly tame and straightforward but soon you will find yourself reaching for a sheet of paper to pencil out puzzles presented in the dialogue to solve a mysterious disappearance. 34422384.review:
[u]~Story~[/u]

Subsurface Circular is a good game in what it desires to be. This is the phrase that I wish to start this review. It's very hard to present the plot without spoiling everything, mainly because it's simple, short and sweet like the game itself. Basically you are a Tek, a robot, more specifically humans finally realized that they are too busy or too lazy to do their own jobs and decided to create the Teks. Robots. Built to take over normal jobs like psychiatrics, athletes, librarians, nannies etc. leaving the scientists, presidents and other "big fish in the sea" to control the rest. What is indeed interesting about is that they have a consciousness, making them more emotional and thoughtful of what is happening around them. That's where you come in. You are a detective Tek, and after an encounter with another robot that approached you in the subway metro regarding the disappearance of his friend, you accept the case and start asking the passengers of the train about information. While you will progress in the game you realize that this whole case is much more deep and happening at a bigger scale.


[u]~Gameplay~[/u]

While I was playing the game I felt like I was watching a theatrical play and I was making all the choices, possibly because everything happened in this train and no where else. The story unravels itself based on the dialogue which makes it more unique then the other choice games I am used to. Basically in some stations Teks come and go and you have to ask them questions regarding their life, profession and lastly the case. Basted on your encounters you will meet different personalities and gather more information. The story takes a dark turn when you, as a robot, start to question yourself if the humans have a hidden hatred for Teks and they are the ones guilty for the disappearances or the robots.

The dialogue is very realistic. The robots make the whole conversations have taste by simply talking about their chores, problems and life. The subject involving life, to me, was indeed interesting and I think it will be for whoever decides to play this game. I say this mainly because the developers did a fantastic job describing life through the "eyes" of a robot.

BUT not everything is perfect and I have to say that the plot becomes boring dragging down along with it the gameplay itself. It feels like the choices you make have no impact and the entire idea of  Teks "come and go" in a subway metro become quickly repetitive. This is the main flaw of the game, the fact that nothing interesting is happening and the end makes everything feel like it was for nothing, very unsatisfying and predictable. Hell, I half expected the game to turn up like that 1994 movie Speed with Sandra Bullock and the characters to realize there is a bomb in the train and there is no way of stopping but no, everything remained the same.


[u]~Graphics and Soundtrack~[/u]


Not much to say. Beautiful visuals, no frame drops and I am firmly positive that it will work smoothly on any decent graphic card. The music was calming and had a happy-go-lucky feeling along with it.


[u]~Conclusion~[/u]

The hidden meaning of this game it's what should motivate you to buy it, not to say that it has a perfect price. With all the questions and details about the disappearances I started to look at the bigger picture and see what this game wants me to understand. After finishing the game I went with my friends to McDonald's and while I was waiting for my friend to come with our orders I started looking around me and spotted an employee that was mopping the floor,the father who was laughing with his daughter while eating, the taxi guy who came to have a launch break and the angry man in the suit who was talking on the phone. Nothing wrong with that after all it is a busy place and a bunch of people come and go, but I saw them for the first time at a bigger scale. The idea of this game was to bring attention to the way society works at a more emotional level. How the mediocre class works almost like robots everyday to live their life, sustain their families and how the high society treats them like robots and their whole existence revolves around work, not seeing that they are talking and working with humans. As a human being, we have feelings, needs, problems and family. Everyday we pass each other on the street not knowing what happens around us, too filled up with stress, jobs and technology to see that we are not equal by money or importance but by respect and honor. Two things that this game wanted express through simple conversations by Teks and how humans feel like their only existence on this planet is to serve them, and they are wrong. Just because they are invisible to them that doesn't mean that they do not think about the actions that they make, actions that led to this amazing story. The game is truly touching once you observe and understand the true meaning of it.


[u]~Strong Points~[/u]

Beautiful graphics. Interesting plot. Realistic dialogue. Good price.

[u]~Weak Points~[/u]

The HUD was not so appealing and the choice interface I found it too basic for a SF game. The ending is disappointing. Nothing big happens to spice up the story leaving all to drown itself.

Rating: 7/10
Developer: Bithell Games
Publisher: Bithell Games
Genre: SF narrative game
Release Date: 17 August 2017

34404140.review:
TL; DR Review:

Pros:
- Game is concise, it's impossible to get lost or otherwise lose focus of what you're supposed to do
- Simple but still well-designed graphics and UI add to the setting
- Storytelling done through exposition in a good way, helps develop the world around you
- Only $6 base price

Cons:
- Game is only 2-and-a-half to 3 hours long at [b]most[/b].
- Though story is great, the replayability is lacking due to shortness of the narrative
- Music consists of only a few tracks, with no OST available.
- Requires patience and a LOT of reading; game is driven by dialog alone, which might bore some.


Long Version Review:

I'd never heard of Bithell Games before now.  Thomas Was Alone and Volume were completely alien titles to me.  I decided to grab this game when a friend pointed it out to me.  They hadn't played it either, but the concept: a mystery story set aboard a subway train with robots, was different enough to intrigue me.  And the execution: a text-based game using words to solve puzzles was instantly my jam.

Enter Subsurface Circular.

The premise of the game is incredibly simple and too the point:  You play as a Tek (the word for robots in this setting) detective who rides the subway, the titular Subsurface Circular, as it follows it's roundabout route.  While on the subway, you meet a fellow Tek, who implores you to investigate a missing friend of his, who is part of a string of unusual and inexplicable disappearances.  Since you cannot leave the train, you must converse with the various passengers, interact with them, help them, to uncover the truth.

The game is made in the Unity engine, and while I'm no programmer/coder, I'm told this is a very good engine, and it shows.  The in-game graphics are crisp and clear, the UI is easy to navigate and use.  The text is easy to read, and my default, moves at a pace that makes it easy to read before it moves along (and even that can adjusted in-game).  The designs of the robots are all quite unique.  They share similar motiffs among types, but they look fantastic, often posed in a manner to convey body language that gives them their own personalities.

The gameplay itself, like the game, is simple.  You engage in conversations with the passengers (each set of passengers is called a 'Sequence' of the subway, gaining 'Focus Points', key words or phrases, which serve as the 'inventory' of the game.  These Points can be used to gain additional information.  With these focus points, you can solve the puzzles given to you by the various passengers.  Some might ask for directions to a stop, others will want to hear a joke.  But don't worry, if you're truly stumped, the game has a hint system!  A '?' icon in the upper right will give you a generalized nudge in the right direction, while the in-game 'Guided Deduction Module' will assist you on the game's much more brain-wracking puzzles.

The story is superb, for a game that's so short.  Pretty much the entirety of the setting is told through the dialog and Focus Points.  While not all information is relevant to the progression of the game, you can learn a massive amount regarding the world through the conversations, adding to your understanding of the setting.  Even then, Bithell kept some details vague and non-specific enough to allow the player's imagination to draw their own conclusions.  Whether you enjoy the 'twist', I feel the story supports itself well enough that the finale will not actually disappoint.

Of course, no game is perfect, and even Subsurface Circular has it's share of smaller, but still prominent issues.  The first, is the runtime.  Even including the puzzles which require you to use your brain seriously to solve, don't expect the game to run longer than 2 or 3 hours.  It's practically anemic.  And while the narrative fits neatly into this, I wish the game had run a bit longer, added more to what was already a solid game.

The fact the game requires you to do pretty much NOTHING but read might be a turn off to some.  Normally I wouldn't include this as a 'Con' for a game, not everyone enjoys having to spend essentially the entire game just reading.

In addition, outside of unlocking an art gallery and a developer commentary in the form of a self-insert character for a second playthrough, there's not a whole lot to replay for, except simply for the sake of indulging in the game's aesthetics and music.

I will point out that these 'downsides' are almost more nitpicks than real negatives.  For a game who's development cycle was a mere [b]four months[/b], there's so much here that I feel it's worth it to play this game, even if perhaps sci-fi isn't really your cup of tea.

All-in-all, Subsurface Circular shows that you don't need years to make a good game.

An excellent short story.

The player takes the role of an android detective investigating disappearances. Along the way he discovers the issues that may face us as we increasingly become more reliant upon automatons.

 It's all very much in the vein of Issac Asimov's works, a good thing in this world of increasingly common action-packed scifi like Star Trek: Into Darkness and The Fifth Element. That genre has its place in our culture, but if  you're into hard sci-fi like The Arrival, you'll appreciate this.

It contains simple logic puzzles, all with an 'easy' button if you're so inclined. The puzzles are very dialogue centered, so if you like talking your way around things this game tickles that fancy.

Dialogue is well written, witty and thoughtful; despite its outward appearance,  never falls into tedium.

Graphics and music are excellent. 

The short duration, about an hour by the studio's reckoning, is something I would argue is not a detriment to a such a game. One that approaches heavy topics such as the place of artificial intelligence in our future. The short story is after all, an efficient medium to impart ideas and thought.

I heartily recommend this game to lovers of Asimov and other sci-fi fans.

34376720.review:
I hadn't heard anything about this game before I saw it on my front page on steam. I casually clicked it, reminding myself that I have an incredible backlog and can't possibly buy more games and then found myself somehow with it in my library five minutes later. I have selective amnesia about the whole situation but since I now owned it, I clearly had to immediately play it. 

[h1]"When the truth is buried, go underground."[/h1]

Subsurface Circular is a short (approximately 90 minutes) visual novel from the maker of Thomas Was Alone and Volume. We play a detective Tek - a robot of the highest intelligence levels. In this universe, robots have been "freed" from ownership, yet still work for the human "management" and seem for all useful purposes, slaves, as they are assigned tasks which they must complete and reset when they're needed for a different purpose. In the beginning of the game we meet a Tek who talks about his missing friend, and we decide that despite not being given the case by management, we are going to work on the disappearance of Teks and solve this crime.

[h1]Thought Provoking[/h1]

It's a neat sci-fi story that really makes you think about the rise of AI and robot sentience, about job replacement and how humanity would feel in this - potentially not that crazily distant - future. Whilst of course, we have no real reality of sentient AI, machinery causing human discontent by replacing certain jobs is certainly a relevant topic and only going to become more so. It was well written, thoughtful and logical with a few small puzzles to make it a little more than just reading. The atmosphere is perfect, from the music to the sound effects, from the graphics to the font and even the way the text pops up and you ask questions. The entire artistic aesthetic really felt authentic to me and allowed me to immerse myself and empathise completely with the robots I was talking - something that's really important to take any genuine emotional impact from the ending.

There are no details I can give without being spoilery - and I would strongly recommend you don't try to get more information as with such a short game, even a small spoiler will detract from the enjoyment and surprise. You'll just have to trust me that the story develops in a satisfying way!

[h1]Don't go expecting Gameplay. This is pure story.[/h1]

Gameplay wise there's not much as this is a visual novel - it is purely clicking the dialogue you want. There is an option at the ending, but this is the only relevant option in the game. The rest will be experienced the same by everyone. If you want to feel like you make an impact or have choices, this is not the game for you. But if you want to be engaged in a story that makes you think, set in a medium that really feels atmospheric then I highly recommend it. I did like the fact that you can set your reading speed as reading faster than the dialogue pops up is very frustrating for a speedy reader.

[h1]And it's a short story.[/h1]

The game is short, there is no beating around the bush but if like me, you read the store description, then you'll know that going in. The developer makes it clear you can complete the game in under 2 hours and as he mentions, this technically means you can complete it and get a refund. If you're planning on completing it and then refunding it, just take a moment to think about how much work goes into making a good game like this - and how honest and upfront the developer was about the playtime. I do think that even at 90 minutes, this game offers excellent entertainment for $5, but I'm also an avid reader, and have no problem paying $5 every week for a new book.

[h1]Hankering for more[/h1]

The game was almost flawless; but I did feel a bit disappointed about the ending. Not the way the game ended itself, but I felt the last sequence or two felt rushed and as if a chunk was missing from the story. We took a big leap at a critical point and then the ending was there. I would have loved if this game had different options and endings, or if there had been a few more sequences as it didn't quite feel perfect. Considering this is such a small indie development; perhaps budgetary constraints were at work. Maybe I'm just greedy, but I'd have happily paid double to experience more of this world. 

This game definitely won't be for everyone. I would recommend it especially to those who enjoy reading books or with a particular interest in the philosophy of future AI, especially if you've read any Asimov (who is quite heavily referenced in the game).

[h1]Despite that, it is still an excellent game and one of the best visual novels I've played, so it gets a massive thumbs up from me.[/h1]

Looks great, but that is it really.  The premise sounded great - i.e. you are a robot and you "learn" new things to cotinue your investigation - I was under the impression that you'd learn new concepts and new "programs" or whatever for your robot brain but actually you just learn some new questions to ask people, and you are literally stuck in one place - its not like other games (e.g. Moneky Island) where you need to walk around and try stuff, you just get a stream of characters who come to you and you have to ask them questions before they leave, and click the red button when it appears.
